case_name: India Sugars and Refineries Ltd. and Salar Jung Sugar Mills Ltd. v. State of Mysore

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 2002 to 2005 and 2014 to 2017 of 1968 were filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 2002 to 2005 and 2014 to 2017 of 1968. Appeals from the judgment

facts.text: Mysore High Court delivered judgment and order dated April 16, 1968 dismissing writ petitions under Article 226.

anchor.surface_text: judgment and order dated April 16, 1968 of the High Court of Mysore dismissing the applications of the appellants under Article 226 of the Constitution for writs,

facts.text: Appellants are India Sugars and Refineries Ltd. situated at Hospet in Bellary District, Mysore.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants are the India Sugars and Refineries Ltd. and the Salar Jung Mills Ltd. The India Sugars and Refineries Ltd. is situated at Hospet in Bellary District in Mysore

facts.text: Salar Jung Sugar Mills Ltd. is situated at Munirabad in Raichur District, Mysore.

anchor.surface_text: and the Salar Jung Sugar Mills Ltd. is situated at Munirabad in Raichur District in Mysore. The appellant, the India Sugars and Refineries Ltd.

facts.text: India Sugars challenged demands for purchase tax and penalty on sugarcane purchases from 1 April 1962 to 30 June 1967.

anchor.surface_text: in four applications number Civil Appeals No. 2015, 2016, 2017 and 2014 of 1968 impeached the demand and companylection made against the appellant for large sums of money as and for purchase tax and penalty on the purchase of sugarcane from the growers for the period 1 April, 1962 to 30 June, 1967

facts.text: Salar Jung challenged similar demands for period 1 July 1963 to 30 June 1967.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Salar Jung Sugar Mills Ltd. in four applications number Civil Appeals No. 2003, 2004, 2005, and 2002 of 1968 asked for similar orders and directions in respect of the period 1 July, 1963 to 30 June, 1967.

facts.text: Mysore Act No. 11 of 1961 came into force on 1 October 1961 including sugarcane in Third Schedule to Mysore Sales Tax Act 1957 at 15%.

anchor.surface_text: By Mysore Act No. 11 of 1961 which came into force on 1 October, 1961 sugarcane was included at Serial No. 11-A in the Third Schedule to the Mysore Sales Tax Act, 1957.

facts.text: Appellants contended no mutual assent for purchase of sugarcane, hence no sale.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants raised three principal companytentions. First, there was numbermutual assent by and between the appellants and the growers of sugarcane

facts.text: Appellants contended they are not dealers under section 2(k) of Mysore Sales Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: Secondly, the appellants are number dealers within the meaning of section 2 k  of the Mysore Sales Tax Act.

facts.text: Appellants contended levy discriminatory under Article 14 due to different rates in states.

anchor.surface_text: Third, the levy of tax on purchase of sugarcane at different rates in different States was discriminatory and in violation of Article 14.

facts.text: Central Government made Sugarcane Control Order 1955 on 27 August 1955 under Essential Commodities Act 1955.

anchor.surface_text: In exercise of the powers companyferred by section 3 of the Essential Commodities Act, 1955 the Central Government on 27 August, 1955 made the Sugarcane Control Order, 1955.

facts.text: Central Government introduced Rule 125-B to Defence of India Rules on 4 October 1963.

anchor.surface_text: On 4 October, 1963 in exercise of the powers companyferred by section 3 of the Defence of India Act, 1962 the Central Government introduced Rule 125-B to the Defence of India Rules.

facts.text: Mysore Government made Mysore Sugarcane Regulation of Supply Order 1963 on 14 November 1963 reserving areas for factories including appellants.

anchor.surface_text: In this background the Mysore Government on 14 November, 1963 in exercise of the powers companyferred by Rule 125-B of the Defence of India Rules brought into existence the Mysore Sugarcane  Regulation of Supply  Order, 1963.

facts.text: Reserved areas required growers to supply 95% of sugarcane to specified factory.

anchor.surface_text: the sugarcane growers in the reserved areas were to supply 95 per cent of sugarcane grown to the factory companycerned.

facts.text: Factories required to enter agreements with each sugarcane grower for purchase.

anchor.surface_text: Every factory to which supply of sugarcane was to be made was required to enter into an agreement with each sugarcane grower to purchase the quantity of sugarcane determined.

facts.text: Central Government amended Sugarcane Control Order 1955 on 14 February 1964.

anchor.surface_text: On 14 February, 1964 in exercise of the powers companyferred by section 3 of the Essential Commodities Act, the Central Government amended the Sugarcane Control Order, 1955.

facts.text: Mysore Government made Mysore Sugarcane Regulation of Supply Munirabad Order 1965 on 15 January 1965 for Salar Jung.

anchor.surface_text: On 15 January, 1965 the Mysore Government in exercise of the Powers companyferred by clause 4 of the Sugarcane Control Order, 1955 as amended and read with the numberification dated 20 February, 1964 made the Mysore Sugarcane  Regulation of Supply   Munirabad  Order, 1965.

facts.text: Salar Jung crushing capacity determined at 1000 tons per day, requiring 1,50,000 tons per season.

anchor.surface_text: The Mysore Sugarcane Order, 1955 determined the crushing capacity of the appellant Salar Jung Sugar Mills Ltd. to be 1000 tons per day and the quantity of sugarcane required by the factory during the crushing season to be 1,50,000 tons.

facts.text: Central Government made Sugarcane Control Order 1966 on 16 July 1966 repealing 1955 order.

anchor.surface_text: On 16 July, 1966 in exercise of the powers companyferred by section 3 of the Essential Commodities Act, 1955 the Central Government made the Sugarcane  Control  Order, 1966 and repealed the Sugarcane  Control  Order, 1955.

facts.text: Supreme Court held transactions constitute sales within Mysore Sales Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: These foregoing features indicate that the transaction in the present case companystituted sale within the meaning of sale in section 2 t  of the Mysore Sales Tax Act, 1957.

facts.text: Supreme Court held appellants are dealers under section 2(k) of Mysore Sales Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held relying on the decision of this Court in State of Andhra Pradesh v. Abdul Bakshi Bros. A.I.R. 1965 S.C. 531 that if a person carries on the business of buying or selling a companymodity it is number necessary that he should sell the same companymodity to become a dealer.

facts.text: Supreme Court held no violation of Article 14 as all Mysore factories treated equally.

anchor.surface_text: It is an indisputable feature in the present appeals that all the factories in Mysore have been treated equally. Different rates in different States are explicable on various grounds.

facts.text: Appeals dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons, the appeals fail and are dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: In fifties, states levied cess on sugarcane brought into sugar factories premises.

anchor.surface_text: In the fifties practically all the States in which sugarcane was grown for the purpose of manufacturing sugar used to levy cess on sugarcane brought into the premises of sugar factories.

facts.text: Supreme Court in Diamond Sugar Mills v. State of U.P. held U.P. Sugarcane Cess Act 1956 ultra vires on 13 December 1960.

holdings.text: The transaction in the present case constituted sale within the meaning of sale in section 2(t) of the Mysore Sales Tax Act, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: These foregoing features indicate that the transaction in the present case constituted sale within the meaning of sale in section 2 t  of the Mysore Sales Tax Act, 1957. Sale is defined in section 2 t  as follows sale with all its grammatical variations and cognate expressions means every transfer of the property in goods by one person to another in the course of trade or business for cash or for deferred payment or other valuable consideration, but does not include a mortgage, hypothecation, charge or pledge.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Mutual assent present in agreements despite controls; features like bargaining for higher price/quantity, advances, inspection, rejection, unconditional appropriation of unascertained goods pass property; analogies to ration sales and precedents (Andhra Sugars, Indian Steel) confirm sales under regulation.

holdings.text: The factories which bought sugarcane could be said to carry on the business of buying and selling sugarcane and the factories are dealers within the meaning of the Mysore Sales Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held relying on the decision of this Court in State of Andhra Pradesh v. Abdul Bakshi Bros. A.I.R. 1965 S.C. 531 that if a person carries on the business of buying or selling a commodity it is not necessary that he should sell the same commodity to become a dealer. The commodity may be converted into another saleable commodity or it may be used as an ingredient in the manufacture of a commodity. Therefore, the factories which bought sugarcane could be said to carry on the business of buying and selling sugarcane and the factories are dealer within the meaning of the Mysore Sales Tax Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Person carrying on business of buying commodity is dealer even if converted/used in manufacture; follows State of Andhra Pradesh v. Abdul Bakshi Bros.

holdings.text: There can be no infraction of Article 14 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: It is an indisputable feature in the present appeals that all the factories in Mysore have been treated equally. Different rates in different States are explicable on various grounds. The quantity available, the conditions of agriculturists, the number of factories will all have distinctive features. Therefore, there can be no infraction of Article 14 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Intra-state equality for all Mysore factories; inter-state rate differences rational based on quantity of sugarcane, agriculturists' conditions, number of factories.

holdings.text: The mere circumstance that the appellants could not collect from the purchasers of the sugar the amount the factories had paid as purchase tax on sugarcane would not alter the nature or quality of tax.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court relying on the decision in Tata Iron Steel Company v. State of Bihar 1958 S.C.R. 1355 said that the mere circumstances that the appellant could not collect from the purchasers of the sugar the amount the factories had paid as purchase tax on sugarcane would not alter the nature or quality of tax.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Inability to pass on tax does not change its nature; sales tax need not be collected from purchaser; follows Tata Iron & Steel Co. v. State of Bihar.

holdings.text: The compulsion of law was not coercion as defined in section 15 of the Indian Contract Act, 1892.

anchor.surface_text: The compulsion of law was not coercion as defined in section 15 of the Indian Contract Act, 1892.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory compulsion to enter agreements does not vitiate consent as coercion; follows Andhra Sugars Ltd. v. State of Andhra Pradesh.

Sugarcane Cess Act, 1956 which empowered the Governor of the State to impose cess on entry of sugarcane into the premises of a factory did number fall within Entry 52 of List II and as there was numberentry in the State List or in the Concurrent List in which the said Act companyld fall, it was beyond the legislative companypetence of the State Legislature.

Madras  Ltd. 1959 S.C.R. 379 in dealing with the assessment of Gannon Dunkerley Co. to sales tax on the value of the materials used in the execution of building companytracts within the taxable turnover of the companypany held that the building companytract was one entire and indivisible transaction and there was numberseparate individual sale of the building materials companyprised in the companystruction.

precedents.case_name: State of Madras v. Gannon Dunkerley Co. (Madras) Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: word sale in Entry 54 List II to be interpreted as per Indian Sale of Goods Act requiring mutual assent, competency, transfer of property, price
precedents.cited_holding: in a building companytract the agreement between the parties was that the companytractor should companystruct the building according to the specifications companytained in the agreement ,and in companysideration therefor receive payment as provided therein, and in such an agreement there was ,neither a companytract to sell the materials used in the companystruction number did the property pass therein as movable

precedents.citation: M s New India Sugar Mills Ltd. v. The Commissioner of Sales Tax, Bihar 1963 Suppl. 2 S.C.R. 459

anchor.surface_text: In M s New India Sugar Mills Ltd. v. The Commissioner of Sales Tax, Bihar 1963 Suppl. 2 S.C.R. 459 a question arose as to whether the despatches of sugar to the Province of Madras by dealers in accordance with the directions issued by the Controller under the Sugar and Sugar Products Control Order, 1946 was liable to be taxed as a sale.

precedents.case_name: New India Sugar Mills Ltd. v. Commissioner of Sales Tax, Bihar
precedents.cited_proposition: despatches of sugar under directions of Controller not sale due to lack of offer, acceptance, volition; prerequisite is contract of sale with privity

anchor.surface_text: These foregoing features indicate that the transaction in the present case constituted sale within the meaning of sale in section 2 t  of the Mysore Sales Tax Act, 1957. Sale is defined in section 2 t  as follows sale with all its grammatical variations and cognate expressions means every transfer of the property in goods by one person to another in the course of trade or business for cash or for deferred payment or other valuable consideration, but does not include a mortgage, hypothecation, charge or pledge.
For these reasons, the appeals fail and are dismissed with costs.

edges.explanation: Present holding finds pith as sale under sales tax Act, distinguishing Diamond Sugar Mills where U.P. Sugarcane Cess Act was ultra vires (pith outside jurisdiction).

h2 holds factories are dealers under section 2(k), addressing i2

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held relying on the decision of this Court in State of Andhra Pradesh v. Abdul Bakshi Bros. A.I.R. 1965 S.C. 531 that if a person carries on the business of buying or selling a commodity it is not necessary that he should sell the same commodity to become a dealer. The commodity may be converted into another saleable commodity or it may be used as an ingredient in the manufacture of a commodity. Therefore, the factories which bought sugarcane could be said to carry on the business of buying and selling sugarcane and the factories are dealer within the meaning of the Mysore Sales Tax Act.
For these reasons, the appeals fail and are dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: It is an indisputable feature in the present appeals that all the factories in Mysore have been treated equally. Different rates in different States are explicable on various grounds. The quantity available, the conditions of agriculturists, the number of factories will all have distinctive features. Therefore, there can be no infraction of Article 14 of the Constitution.
For these reasons, the appeals fail and are dismissed with costs.
